title: Prince Harry sues The Sun and Daily Mirror owners over ‘phone-hacking’
text:
The Palace confirmed that the claims have been filed at the High Court (Picture: Getty)

Buckingham Palace has confirmed that Prince Harry is taking legal action against the bosses of The Sun and the Daily Mirror.

The Duke of Sussex has begun the legal process of suing the owners of the two national newspapers in relation to alleged phone-hacking.

The Palace confirmed on Friday that the claims have been filed at the High Court over alleged illegal interception of voicemail messages.

However, as the claims are not yet public there is no further information on the allegations at this time.

A spokesperson for News Group Newspapers, publishers of The Sun and the now-defunct News of the World, said: ‘We confirm that a claim has been issued by the Duke of Sussex.

‘We have no further comment to make at the current time’.

A source at Reach plc, which owns the Mirror, said they were aware that proceedings had been issued but had not yet received them, so they were unable to comment further.

It is thought that the case could be related to the phone hacking scandal of the early 2000s, when he had a mobile telephone as a teenager.

Harry may be alleging he was the victim of unlawful information gathering for the purpose of publishing articles about him.

It is thought the allegations date back to the phone hacking scandal (Picture: Samir Hussein/WireImage)

This could be the first time a serving member of the Royal family could testify in the witness box at a trial against the media.

A legal source told Byline Investigates, who revealed the court documents, that: ‘An appearance by the Prince in the witness box would immediately make this an historic moment in British law.

‘There are strong matters of principle at stake here for the prince. A lot of work has gone into preparing these cases to the point they can be formally filed.

‘His legal team plainly feels there are cases to be answered here.’

Actor Hugh Grant is among the celebrities who have accepted damages from the Mirror group, which was under the editorship of Piers Morgan at the time.

Meanwhile, Sir Elton John, Elizabeth Hurley and Heather Mills settled claims against Rupert Murdoch’s News Group Newspapers.

Nathan Sparkes, of the campaign group Hacked Off said the case ‘shows how much more of the phone hacking scandal may yet reach the public domain.’

Former deputy editor at the News of the World and the Sunday Mirror, Paul Connew, told the BBC Prince Harry was ‘determined to attack the popular press’ over ‘allegations which date back about 15 years.’

He added: ‘Prince William has a more mature take of the press and I expect that in the long run Prince Harry could come to regret this.’

The News of the World closed in July 2011 at the height of the phone hacking scandal.

The two newspaper groups have paid out over £500 million in settlements to victims.

description: Buckingham Palace confirmed that Prince Harry is suing owners of The Sun and Daily Mirror over alleged phone-hacking.
